Two simple brackets for the Inventables X-Carve or a Shapeoko 2 upgrade.

A bracket to hold a micro-switch for the Z axis's home, allowing the Z carriage to come up to it. And one to allow the X and Y axis's stop to be adjusted, allowing the carriage to stop before colliding with any mechanical elements.

Big holes should take a 5mm bolt. Z axis stop made for a 9.5mm centres micro-switch mount.

Marked as 'work in progress' because more brackets and parts may be added as the machine is played with. But the first two parts work fine.

A collection of different tyres, meant to be printed with ninjaflex or similar soft filament.
Rear tyres have an aggressive tread pattern whilst the fronts are more or less smooth.
There's also different stiffness for each tyre.

They should fit Tamiya 1:14 scale rims and the ones I've uploaded for the printed truck.

If you're running duals on the rear and single up front I'd recommend soft on rear wheels and medium on the front.

You can see this kind of tyre in my project video for this truck:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rr9fuMH2_O4

The uploaded ones are slightly updated and should flex better/more evenly.

2016-07-12: Added solid tyre models, change their strength by adjusting infill percentage and infill width.

Check me out at:
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/MrCrankyfaceProjects
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/mr.crankyface/
3d hubs: https://www.3dhubs.com/malm%C3%B6/hubs/mrcrankyface
Patreon: http://patreon.com/Mrcrankyface

As always with flexible filaments, print slow.
You may need to adjust your extrusion width to get these perfect as they have a fair amount of 'thin walls'.

REAL WORLD PROBLEM
Have you ever wanted to illuminate an outdoor area, but you didn't want to bother hassling with extension cords? I have.
Have you ever had a great outdoor lamp, but didn't have anywhere to hang it? I have.
The portable spotlight aims to solve these problems .

SOLUTION
The portable spotlight removes the need for troublesome cords because it is battery powered.​It is also portable because of the integrated C-clamp which lets you attach it to any ledge that is thicker than 2.5 inches.

OBJECT DESCRIPTION
The portable spotlight is mostly made out of 3D printed PLA plastic.
It illuminates dark spaces with its 12V LED bulb that is powered by
6 AAA batteries.Thanks to its arm channels, the lamp also offers multi directional illumination.

-First off I would like to give credit where credit is due: Thank you Airtripper for the awesome extruder! If anyone is interested in the Airtripper BSP Extruder, you can find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126778

-This is a great little extruder mounting system I conjured up in solidworks. It is mainly design for the sE1X from Mobious Robotics (http://mobious.org) but will work with any design that uses 2020 extrusion as a gantry. It does have 2 M5 holes so you can secure it in place with some flat head m5-8's.
-The second part simply mounts to the bottom of the Airtripper Extruder body using 2 m5-10s and 2 m5 hex nuts.

Enjoy!

description.text: Ajedrez inspirado en piezas torneadas

This set of parts adds a fume hood to your Cupcake CNC that's meant to be used along with the Cupcake "oven" covers:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13937 There are holes for the filament feed, Z-rod access (for both left and right handed user), and a 3" port that you can hook up to the air handling solution of your choice (maybe this? http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7152). It sets on the top bolts of the Cupcake for easy installation an removal. More pics here:
flickr.com/photos/builttospec/6103855648/in/photostream

Basically just cut the PETG parts, snap them together, and seal the thing up with clear packing tape to make the main body. Ideally you'd use this with the MakerBot spindle or a similar spindle setup with a 1/4" HDPE filament feed tube. The two small circular parts are washers for the push connect hardware for the filament tube that's installed in the center of the housing. You'll need to extend one of the Z rods through the top of the enclosure or use a Z-min endstop to zero the Z-axis with the hood in place:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4762 The 3" port on the back is simply a 3" drain port from Home Depot. I experimented with using laser cut sticky backed EVA foam (craft foam) for the gaskets on this project and it worked out reasonably well. Just cut and stick where the outlines for the gaskets are. There's a gasket for the port on the back and the two Z-rod access holes (use the one with the hole for the Z-rod extension and the solid one to seal off the other).
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/36k25eR0t0q

Remixed this for the 5 mm thick Acrylic I had on hand for the front window. Pushed the nut and bolt holes down lower, lengthening the whole piece and moving the holes to drill in the Plexiglass away from the top edge. Knocked it together using TinkerCad blocks and tubes.

I made the fit to the top edge really tight so if you want it a bit looser maybe file the inside edge of the top of the hook to taste.

Last Picture: May I suggest everyone with a CTC gets a cheap Nut spinner set. It's made life so much easier tightening stuff up. The 5.5 mm one is whats needed for those fiddly nuts used on all those 3 mm bolts.
Blocks & tubes in TinkerCad

title: O-7X Heavy Assault Crawler (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This robot was designed for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics (stat cards for this are included with the pictures). If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%. The split version would benefit from support material for the legs.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

comments.text: Thank you for uploading this design, it is amazing! I am truly sorry for all of the people that are giving you trouble because they are just cherry picking the Bible and don't get the whole message or reason behind the events. I am definitely printing this and I cant wait to see the other amazing models you make in the future! God Bless and Happy Resurrection Sunday/ Easter!!!

comments.author: Caleb_J_2012

comments.text: Hey this is an awesome design! Just printed one as a Baptism gift!  Just wanted to flag for you that there is an error in the model... the top Support that connects the G to the O in GOD is not complete all the way through the model.  I noticed when mine was printing that it wasn't connecting and so I reviewed the STL and saw the issue.  I have a corrected STL, but I figured you should correct and repost rather than have me post as "Remix".  The issue doesn't really impact the overall print, but just a small thing to clean up so I figured I'd flag it for you. Overall, a really nice piece of work!  Thank you!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fCWr1SAzvJl

This is a single Sided approach to this board. But the version 1.1V thats in the makerbot SVN. I tested this board by hooking up an 5v arduino + GND then ran a magnetic strip over the IC. The activity light started blinking! So it looks like everything is working. This is also my first board I have laid out that was a double sided board converted to a single. Some places are "tight" but its doable. I have ohm'ed out all my connections and everything is great. Video of it in action here:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/4170462649/
Enjoy. Ril3y

Paint PCB with a black primer.  Laser etch the designs.  (a few times is better.  Normally this is not needed.  Due to the small chip this is a good idea)  Then place board in ferric chloride or rub the ferric chloride on the board directly.  (This is what I do).
Remove and have fun.  Oh and I used a header vs the CDROM cable that it called for.  I want to test this out on the contraptor stuff to see how accurate I can get :) so no need for that specific port.

Of all the sketches in the [email protected] Project Shellter Workshop Sketches I immediately thought this one had the most potential to translate into 3D. Apparently I wasn't the only one. ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14046 for one.) I made some major design choices to make it (1) printable and (2) a good shell for the hermit crabs. (Check the wireframe to see the sweet ledge inside.) Unfortunately I'm still not 100% sure it'll print as-is. I hope someone prints it and gives me feedback.
Scale before printing. This wasn't made with any sense of scale in mind.

text = Colby Nelson
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ilAkByiBXU9

I wanted to create a cartesian printer with minimal footprint in relation to the available print bed.

Target is 300x300 outer dimensions to print on 215x215 borosilicate glass I have around.
The extrusion is based on RichRap's fantastic Sli3dr concept, as this was the basic inspiration.

After some first parts I reverted to the KISS principle, each part should provide one function.
The GT2 belts are on separate levels and do not cross.
The 608 bearings can be found in your children's skates, and fit on the holders without screws.

There will be regular updates as project progresses.

Level One

  • First publish of rod holders
  • Z escalator parts
  • front bearing mounts

BOM:

Z escalator:
1 x 400mm 8mm trapezoid lead screw (I use TR8x1.5 with 2133.33 steps/mm)
1 x 8mm trapezoid nut TR8x1.5 17x15mm
2 x 450mm, 8mm sliding rods
2 x LM8UU or RJ4JP-01-08

XY:
2 x GT2 timing belts (those from Kossel Mini build work perfectly)
8 x 608 bearing
2 x 290mm 8mm rod for X
2 x 250mm 8mm rod for Y
4 x LM8UU / Igus RJ4JP-01-08

Find it on github: https://github.com/gweber/minicore

description.text:
This is my version of a tricopter tilt mechanism. It is build around a Turnigy TGY-210DMH, any servo of the same size will fit. The servo is lifted 5mm above ground, so you don't need to cut some parts of the servo.

You need 4 small zip-ties to fix the bottom-part to the arm and a bigger one for the servo. The small bottom-part is strong enough to hold the motor, the servo-holder will only work against the torque of the steering. The updated servo-holder now has holes for smaller zip-ties.

There is only one updated universal motor-holder, wich fits to all variants. Use a M3-30mm for the axe, a 30mm screw will exact match with the updated design. it is a bit asymetrical to leave a bit more room for the servo. Be sure the servo is in middle-position and pull the servo in position by tightening the screw. Don't pull it to tight, use blue loctite only on the servo-side.

This tilt is inspired by David Windestals tilt from rcexplorer.se, but as I didn't have a M3-40mm, so it came to my own version. The updated Version now works with 10 mm, 12.5 mm or 14 mm arms.

Update Sept. 2016: There is a new motor-holder that is used with a servo-arm. You need an single-side arm with two holes on 10mm and 15mm. The servo arm is fixed with two small screws (10mm long), wich come with your servo.

I did another Version with splined servo-mount, but my printer isn't able to print this in a usable way. So use the version with called '...servohorn' when the universal_tilt_motor without splines doesn't work for you.

Does it work for you?

Printer:

CTC 3D Printer, Makerbot Dual clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

100%

Update 28.3.2016: 12.5mm and 14mm and motorholder

Added new arm-sizes and updated the motor-holder. Its slightly asymetrical to add some space between motor and servo. Renamed the 10mm-parts.

comments.text: Not sure how the servo fits with no splines or place to mount a horn.
comments.author: MidTenMaker

comments.text: It's a very very thight fit. The servo gear will not slip in the hole by itself, you need to drag it with the screw and you need an all metal gear servo. The servo-gear will rasp some scrapers inside of the hole. I print with 0,2mm, so the surface of the part ist still a bith rough. Do not widen the servo-holes with a drill. You will only need a 3mm-drill to clean up  the holes for the axis.

title: Spool Roller for Folger Tech 2020 i3

description.text:
I designed these to sit on top of a Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3 printer, but it would probably work with any 2020 frame printer. It has been tested with spools 8.5 inches diameter down to 4.5 inches diameter. You can just drop the spool in the mount and feed the filament into the extruder, and you are ready to go. No fiddling with spindles, shafts, hubs or axles. It just sits securely cradled in the rollers, and rolls freely.

They are designed to slide left and right to accommodate different spool widths. The 2020 insert does not lock in place like a T-Nut. It will just keep it from tipping over or coming off. Put the insert into the 2020 slot and then slide it into the slot on the spool bracket mount.. Put in a 10mm M3 machine screw to hold it against the bracket, and the whole assembly should all slide freely left and right in the 2020 slot, while still remaining perfectly vertical and securely attached. You only need one insert, at the front. There are two slots so the left and right brackets can be identical. The inner bracket fits into the slot on the base of the outer bracket for added strength and stability.

You will need to print two full sets, one for each side. They are identical, so no mirroring is required. I've added a plated set that will print both sides in one print.

The bearings are just common 608ZZ bearings. You will need two M3 machine screws 20mm or longer, and two M3 nuts to put it all together, plus the M3x10 for the 2020 insert.

It works well with with my Filament Guide and Filter which is what you see in the photos between the brackets.

Update 3/23/2016
Updated STL files to Version 5. It is slightly less tall, and with openings in the main bracket reducing the filament necessary when printing, without any loss of strength. Because it is slightly shorter, you will need to reprint both the inner and main brackets. There are now three versions of the main bracket, solid, with round cutouts, and with a more open cutout pattern. Any of the three will work with the same inner bracket.

All files are now rotated into the best orientation for printing. I also added a plated set that will let you print everything for both sides at the same time.

Printer:

Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

I used 30% infill for strength.

Notes:

I tap the 2020 insert with an M3 tap after printing, but you should also be able to self tap it with an M3 bolt.
Designed in OnShape

title: "I Moustache You a Question" Bottle Topper

description.text:
Now you can have a luxurious lip caterpillar every sip from a bottle! Print this mustache and mount it to the neck of your bottle of pop.

This was designed to fit a generic bottle neck. If you want to have it fit a specific bottle, measure the bottle with a ruler or caliper, and design the file in Tinkercad! The how to video is included.

Make the Ring
  1. On a new workplace bring out 2 Cylinders from the Geometric menu
  2. Bring out the Ruler Helper tool, and place it in the corner
  3. Change the scale of the Cylinder to match the size of the bottle (26mm x 26mm x 5mm)
  4. Change the scale of the second Cylinder to be slightly larger than the size of the bottle (30mm x 30mm x 3mm)
  5. Turn the first Cylinder (26x26x5 cylinder) to a Hole in the Inspector
  6. Select both Cylinder using Shift Select or Drag Select
  7. Use the Adjust Align tool
  8. Click the middle pin on the width and the length (NOT the height)
  9. Select both Cylinders
  10. Group to make the Hole cut
  11. Bring out a Box from the Geometric menu
  12. Change the width to 3mm
  13. Place Box on the edge of the ring
  14. Make the Box a Hole
  15. Select both the ring and the Box
  16. Use the Adjust Align tool
  17. Click the middle pin on the width
  18. Select the ring and the Box
  19. Group to make the Hole cut
Make the Mustache
  1. From the Shape Generators > TinkerCad Menu, bring out an Extrusion shape
  2. Use the Gear in the Inspector window to make sure the vectors Snap
  3. Warp the four vectors in the Inspector window
  4. Play around! Have a lot of fun making a new shape!
  5. When you are happy with one half of the mustache, change the height to 5mm
  6. Move the half mustache into place on the ring
  7. Edit > Duplicate the half mustache
  8. Use the Adjust Mirror tool
  9. Click on the arrows along the width
  10. Move the Mirrored Duplicated half into place
  11. Select both sides of the mustache with Shift Select
  12. Group
  13. Select the ring and the mustache with Drag Select or Shift Select
  14. Use the Adjust Align tool
  15. Click the middle pin on the width
  16. Select all with Drag Select or Shift Select
  17. Group
  18. Select .STL
  19. Bring your downloaded file into MakerBot Desktop
  20. Print!

print_settings.Notes:: Ignore the rough print in the photos.  I revised the part to use less fillet on the cap, and it will print much smoother than the one in the photos.

description.text:
I designed this filament filter guide for the Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3. It serves as a filament guide, and a filament filter all in one.

To use the filter, put a piece of foam sponge (or whatever else you like to use for your filter material) around the filament, then slide the filament through the side of the guide and the filter down into the square pocket. Slide on the front cap to keep the filter from getting pushed out of the top, then drop the retainer ring over the whole thing to insure the cap can't fall off.

Alternatively, you can slide the filament into place in the guide, and stuff the filter in around it before putting on the cap and ring.

Some people put 3-n-1 oil or canola oil on the filter, and say that helps cut down on jams.

This is probably overly complex, but it started as just a filament guide, then I added the filter box, then the cap, because the filter would occasionally get pushed out on a retract, or when the head moved from the extreme left or right back to center under the filter. I added the ring after the cap fell off once. I could have made the cap tighter, but I wanted it to all be easy to quickly slide together, and the ring is really easy to use. All together, everything is held in place and can't come apart by itself, regardless of how much the printer or the filament moves.

I use this with my new spool holder which you can also see in the photos.

Printer:

Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I use 0.2 layer height, and 30% infill, but it probably doesn't matter. Use a T-nut to hold it in place on the 2020 bar above the printer.

Ignore the rough print in the photos. I revised the part to use less fillet on the cap, and it will print much smoother than the one in the photos.

comments.text: Do you feel as though this would be prone to fail near the peak of the build height on the folgertech 2020? It seems as though the filament would be exiting the filter/guide at an extreme angle to make it to the raised print head, which may snap the filament or cause so much resistance on the edge of the guide that it strips the filament in the extruder.

This is used to remove the bearing holders for the circa 90's Avid Arch Supreme linear pull brakes. I think at the time you could just buy full replacements (along with the tool), but now both are impossible to find. With this tool the brake arms can be completely disassembled and the bearings can be more easily removed and replaced.

Print and press some bits of wire clothes hanger into the holes. To remove the bearings, the center insert needs to be pushed to the side (which can be difficult) and the bearings tapped out with something like a drift punch. The bearings can't be pushed all the way through because the center is narrower.

author: 3dbeta

description.text:
Video of it in action! https://youtu.be/4yeiTEQm_LM

Here are the files for an opensource rope making machine I designed. It is possible to 3d print the parts, however I used a MPCNC to cut the parts out of 1/2 inch and 1/4 inch plywood. Not every detail is modeled and these files would require additional work to be printed. I welcome anyone to remix and modify the files Here they are at GrabCadhttps://grabcad.com/library/465731 .

All bolts are 5/16th.

The small gear has a recessed pocket for a nut that is glued in place using locktite and then epoxied. Mounting, handle design and attachment and spacers between the plates are modeled. I didn't have a great way to do that so I kludged it together. From the pictures you should get an idea, but I think pretty much anyone could do better.

comments.text: I have designed gears that I can cut on an Epilog Laser, and I was thinking I could use them to make a rope maker.

This is my latest VEX robotics chassis creation, continuing on the theme of my previous designs. It is a chassis for a four motored, four mecanum wheeled, programmable robot using VEX EDR components.

Extendable by attaching to the front and back bumpers, or the micro-controller's mounting points.

I would only suggest printing the sleeker, more compact version two (purple in photos). Version one (black in photos) is only included for insight into my design process.

While this chassis will accept either 3-wire or 2-wire EDR motors, it is NOT designed to accommodate motors with Integrated Encoder Modules. I figured the likelihood that someone would want mecanum wheels with integrated encoders was low; I hope I'm not wrong.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

Default

Attach the motors to the inside of the chassis using a couple of standard motor mount screws each.

A lock collar in each of the slots by the motors will hold the square shafts to the chassis. A Teflon washer between the chassis and each wheel is probably a good idea to reduce friction. A lock collar on the outside of each wheel will hold them on.

The battery is intended to be attached to the bottom using twist ties.

It's a little difficult to position and hold a nut on the underside of the micro-controller mount points. My apologies. I was able to use a wrench from the side.

Programming it

One example: http://www.robotc.net/blog/2011/11/22/vex-mecanum-drive-using-robotc/

description.text:
Untested, need to find the time to get the hardware but I see belt tensioners mentioned often and I wanted to try and make one for the Duplicator i3's X-Axis. My idea is to sort of losely pretension the belt and then pull it tight with the m3 bot/nut section that slides along the slot. As I said this is untested, so I will be updating it as I go. Looking at the bottom of the printer, if this works for the X-Axis I think it should also work for the bottom as it seems to have the same mounting holes as the top does.

Update 3/12: I just realized I had measured the belt doubled on mine. I'm still using the stock belt which is around 1.25mm thick and I've decreased the gap size to keep the same outer distance but thicken up the section the belt loops around to strengthen it. The gap is now 1.75mm wide instead of the old 2.625mm. I've left both versions still there for now but if anyone has a problem with maybe a third party belt in the smaller gap on the v2 I will make the changes to better fit it.

Hardware required:
6mm and 12mm M4 (or 11mm if there is such a thing?) to mount the main section and a 1 1/2" M3 hex bolt with M3 nut to fit into that slot you see on the main section.

Wanhao Duplicator i3

description.text:
We needed a small shelf to hold a bottle of liquid soap in our bathroom and my wife suggested I adapt my robot cell phone holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1293141 and make a small soap shelf - and since I really love making those robot-like models she didn't need to ask twice.

The shelf is 8x8cm, this size fits all the hand soap bottles I could find in my home.

This model is available in two versions - the first version has some small problems, but nothing you can't fix with just a little quality time with some sandpaper, the second version should fix all the problem with the first version but I haven't printed it myself yet.

The model has 3 parts, they can all be printed together on the same bed using the same settings, I printed it in PLA, 0.2mm layer height, 10% infill and no supports.

The body

The body should be printed sitting down with no support and 5-10% infill.

The body has massive overhangs that are likely to make you slicer go crazy but my printer had no trouble printing them - the bottom-back of the arms looks bad but I don't care because nobody will look at the back side of a wall mounted shelf.

The model actually has built in support for all the problem parts, you need to remove two thin pieces of plastic supporting the bottom of the hands and arms on both sides.

In the V2 model there are also two pieces of "support" on the top of both shoulders - those are there to increase the layer time of the topmost layers, without them the plastic doesn't have time to cool down and the body-to-head connector comes out really deformed.

This part is surprisingly strong with 10% infill and has no problem supporting the weight of the soap bottle and the pressure applied when using it.

The head

Both the V1 and V2 versions share the same head design.

The head should be printed face up, infill is not important since this part doesn't need to support any weight.

The head part for the body-head connector is a little too big to fit a malformed body-side part of the connector from the V1 body, you may need a tiny bit of glue.

The wall plate

The wall plate should be printed wider part down with 5-10% infill and no support.

The wall plate is designed for two 3mm screws 38mm apart the narrower part goes on the wall and the wider part goes into a slot on the robot's back.

There are two square holes on the bottom, those are for the screw heads, the bridging of those comes out horrible but nobody will know because they will be inside the robot.

In the V1 model the tolerances are way too small and unless your printer is perfectly calibrated it will need a bit of sanding, the V2 model should be easier to fit.

This model was designed using SketchUp Make, fixed up using Microsoft 3D Builder and printed using Cura on a Robo3D R1+

Hope you like this model, if you like it check out the rest my robots on thingiverse

Doesn't Matter

title: Millennium Falcon Bin for Harbor Freight Organizer (X-Wing TMG)

description.text:
Huge, full-height bin made to fit a YT-1300 from the X-Wing game. The bin is slightly smaller at the bottom, unlike my half-height bins (and the Tie ones), because it seems to fit better this way.

This bin is based off this container by Atila Sanchez. The major change (other than putting it in a HF-sized form factor) is to tilt the Falcon so that the radar dish is safely out of harm's way. I end up putting a little foam on top of the back corner to hold it nicely in place.

I'll be honest: I'm not totally happy with this bin. However, it's quite functional, and I'm not sure how to improve without adding additional parts. Orienting the Falcon inverted might be better. Anyway, I'm moving on for now -- I rarely fly this ship anyway :).

I've also included a few pictures of the models that led up to this, in case you're interested in how these come together (for me).

The Teardrop are is a geometrical shape which is used whenever a horizontal hole is printed.
This avoids overhangs greater than 45Â° at the top of the hole, which are not (or at least not easily and clean) printable on FDM printers without support material. The problem with teardrop holes is, that they need considerably more space. This can be a real problem, when the main object is limited in size for one reason or another. Flat Teardrops solve this problem.
The solution is simple. Although overhangs > 45Â° are a problem in 3D printing, reasonably short bridges arenâ€™t!
So why not just cut off the dead space in the tip of a teardrop? See http://pleasantsoftware.com/developer/3d/2011/11/29/flat-teardrop/ for more details.

Copy & paste this into your copy of the Libs.scad library (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6021) The module makes use of the resolution function of the Libs.scad library. If you add the flatteardrop module to this library (as I did on my computer), it just works. If you plan to use the flatteardrop module separately, you might want to comment out the line $fn=resolution(radius); or set $fn to a fixed value (e.g. 36).

comments.text: Truncated teardrops have been in use for a while, but I've switched to using polygonal holes, usually with 6 or 8 sides. The benefit of this is that I can easily calculate the polygon's diameter so that the incircle diameter matches the screw/rod that is supposed to fit inside. I multiply the diameter by 7/6 for hexagons and 13/12 for octagons. Rotated so that they have a flat on top, these avoid an overhang exceeding 45 degrees and center the incircle in the hole so that if a poorly calibrated printer makes drilling necessary, the drill will stay centered rather than moving the hole upward.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Hexagonal/octagonal holes also seem like a more natural fit for the STL filetype, where even "circular" holes become many-sided polygons anyway!  Depending on the model, I'm sure you'd see a significant reduction in file size.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

author: danielkmx

description.text:
This thing will be discussed in detail on the 3D Printing Today Podcast:
threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com or search the iTunes music store or stitcher radio for "3D Printing Today"

This thing is a modification of the Raise3D N2 and N2+ bed. The bed as delivered is a fixed position, factory leveled bed. Unfortunately, the folks at Raise3D did not take into account the probability of the bed going out of level, which it did for me. They also do not take into account when a user has a number of build plates and the plate height changes. Changing the distance between the hotend and the plate with the adjustment screw is tedious and painful. With this mod you can adjust it on the fly and get it just right without having to stop everything again and again. Additionally there were 2 major safety issues related to the bed which I address in this modification:

  1. Raising the bed off the lock screws which would eventually eat through the insulation fish paper Raise3D used which in turn would short out the bed. We are told by Raise3D that they only used these for the first batch of N2s that were delivered and that the path of the heater traces are no longer on these screws... and they changed the screws to nylon tipped.
  2. Insulating the edges and exposed solder points under the bed to protect against shorts which could easily be caused by using binder clips to hold the plate on to the bed. This condition is still apparent in machines being delivered.

The modification includes:

  1. Replacing the 9 M3 bolts that currently hold the bed downward on to the lockscrews with 5 longer bolts.
  2. Insulating parts of the underside of the bed with Kapton tape
  3. Adding lock nuts over PETG washers immediately under the bed
  4. Adding compression springs
  5. Adding PETG stabilizers which the springs sit on
  6. Adding PETG wing nuts with nylon insert lock nuts

Parts List:
1.qty of 5 of, Type 18-8 Stainless Steel Flat-Head Socket Cap Screw, DIN 7991-A2, M3 Thread, 35MM Long, Packs of 50 McMaster Carr #92125A141

  1. Qty of 5 13/32" x 1" Compression Spring; Midwest Fastener Corp. (1) 13/32" x 1" Compression Spring - M159
    http://www.tooldepot247.com/catalogsearch/result/?q=M159
  2. Qty of 10 M3 Nylon insert lock nuts
    http://www.mcmaster.com/#nylon-insert-locknuts/=11hwvxd
  3. 5 printed washers
  4. 5 printed spring stabilizers
  5. 5 printed wing nuts. These were made using the AWESOME Ultimate Nut Knob Generator from wstein, thing number; 713300

UNPLUG the bot! if you are not sure what you are doing then i suggest NOT doing this. This Mod may be more complex for casual users which was why I tried to convince Raise3D to abandon the fixed bed approach.

I suggest printing all of the parts in a higher temp filament such as PETG or nylon. This modification will use about 3/4 of an inch of Z height from the build area.
To start, I removed the hot glue from the bed heater connection using a heat gun. You can also dab it with alcohol to get it to soften. Disconnect the bed.
Next I remove the 9 bolts/nuts holding the bed down and remove the bed. Remove the insulators which the lock screws press against. I left the lock screws in place. They do not get in the way.
Add thick kapton tape to the edges of the bed to protect against damage from use of clips for the build plate(note the pic of the heater traces along the edge of the underside of the bed). Also add kapton over the exposed surface mount resistor right next to where the center bolt goes through as well as the exposed connections by the heater's connectors.
Next put on the new longer M3 screws. Note the nylon locking nuts will in time loosen since they will be close to the heater and they are rated to 102C. I set my HBP to 95C for ABS. Some Locktight might be a good idea.
Add the springs and the stabilizers then a small piece of tape to hold them all together when you flip the bed over to replace it on the Z shelf. Make sure all the bolts are through their respective holes then remove the tape. Then compress each spring with one hand above and one hand below and screw on the wing nut with an M3 locknut set into it.
You will also need to move the limit switch bracket from under the Z shelf to above so that the limit switch thumbscrew can reach the limit switch.
Adjusting:
Plug the Printer in and let it boot. Go to the utilities menu and home the z axis then disable the motors(the icon in the upper left corner). Then move the extruder carriage manually to each position. When adjusted right, you want the entire motion distance between the bed and the bottom to be minimal. The springs should be partially compressed and tight.
Tighten all 5 points of the bed. Best way to do this is again compressing each spring one at a time with one hand above and one below. Next manually raise the bed by rotating the Z rods you want to move the bed upwards so that the head of the thumbscrew for the limit clicks the switch. Adjust the thumbscrew as needed. Then use a biz card or thick card stock as a feeler and position the nozzle over each bolt and adjust to the nozzle accordingly. I start in the center then go around, then do it again.

The trick to getting this right are the springs. These springs are the right size and strength to hold, in combination, about 40lbs without them compressing further. It has been argued that for the N2+ model with a print that could fill the entire 2 foot tall bed, these springs would compress and the object would then miss layers and ruin the print. If I were worried about printing that tall with that high a weight I'd either clamp the bed upwards so the springs would not compress or simply add four more springs without the bolts going through them using the four holes that are left unused from the previous approach. However, the springs i spec’ed, The Midwest fastener #M159… I tested it with a digital scale. At mid compression each holds up 8lbs of pressure. 8x5=40… that’s 40lbs of pressure before the 5 springs are compressed further… that’s 18 spools of filament!

My bed is still rock solid. No more too low in the front and too close in the back. I also can adjust bed height on the fly and not blind via the limit switch screw. There is zero x/y motion and I am finding the bed stays nice and level. I only need to check it when I remove/replace the plate. Thanks to the center bolt/spring I am able to adjust the bed to ensure there is no crowning effect as seen on 4 point leveling approaches on larger bed machines.

comments.text: Hmm. I made a modified version of this and it works great. However, when leveling I take a slightly different approach: I loosen the center screw, adjust the corners, and then tighten the center only enough to prevent crowning. If I tighten the center first, then the plate is pivoting around that as I adjust the corners, and it is a bit hard to get it right.

description.text:
I designed this for my Mendel90, but really it can be used for any printer.

There are times where I want to purge the old filament out and 'start' the new filament through the extruder, but I don't want the extruded filament to stick the heated glass bed. I came up with this "purge pan" based on designs we use at work (I work with plastic injection molding) where these types of devices are quite common.

The idea is you'd place this purge pan on your print bed and purge the old filament along with the new filament into the purge pan instead of on the heated print bed. The small footprint of the purge pan keeps it from sticking to the heated print bed.

I printed mine upside down, thus explaining the nasty appearance inside the 'bowl', but its purpose is just to collect purged and wasted plastic, so it doesn't need to be pretty.

title: Blackout Spider Hex Gimbal Mount (Storm32 + MotorPixie Mini Gimbal)

description.text:
So I was inspired by using this gimbal on my hex:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:543822/

I wanted to be able to have a race copter and an option to mount a gimbal very fast and with no screws etc...

So for using this gimbal u need everything from the original gimbal, but the "roll motor mount".
Just use the attached motor mount (tb_spider_storm32_gimbal.stl) here. To use it, u will also need my "Blackout Spider Hex Landing Gear 2", that can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1288262

Note:
I used some other motors than the MotorPixie mentioned motors, so if you use this motors:
Quanum 2208 Precision Brushless Gimbal Motor (GoPRO size 100-200g):
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__42247__Quanum_2208_Precision_Brushless_Gimbal_Motor_GoPRO_size_100_200g_.html

u will need the attached "gimbal arm long" file, which is a longer version of the original gimbal.

With the new updated version, u have to remove the battery plate on the bottom.

UPDATE: Aprilm 11th 2016:

  • Uploaded a new (higher) Gimbalmount -> now you have enough space for landing with gimbal.
  • Storm32 housing added -> u need 2 screws (holes already at the frame) to attach it on the bottom.

Please note this is a work in progress,

Have fun!

author: makeitman4

description.text:
This is a tool to help you customize your own personal replacement for the red button-top on a Staples easy button.

It's customizable, sort of. Not OpenSCAD customizable; you use Autodesk 123D Design or other software capable of working with the source files.
I did export a .sat (STEP) file. It doesn't have the text part in it; you need to generate your own text that fits, extruded to 25mm, to work.

Caveat: Instructions are for 123D Design users. Any other software, and you're on your own. I dunno, approximate, improvise.

  1. Edit your catchphrase. Select the text block and enter the word(s) you want and select the font (mouseover the gear icon that appears when it's selected). Also change Height to resize the letters. Make sure it fits inside the 35mm radius circle underneath it.
  2. Select Extrude Text and extrude it to 25mm.
  3. Extruding them should have merged the letters automatically with the 35mm circle beneath them. If not, then merge the letters with the base circle (use the menu bar or [ character and select all parts, then press Enter).
  4. Move the cylinder labeled Ltr Cutout 100mm up (-100), then subtract it (that's the ] character) from the letters.
  5. Move the cylinder marked Btn Cutout 100mm down (+100) and intersect it (the \ character) with the letters.
  6. Select all your letters and move them 100mm left.
  7. If you are doing a single nozzle print, merge all the letters with the blank button and export as .stl.
  8. If you are making a 2-color print, i.e. two print nozzles loaded with different filaments, export the two parts separately. I say two parts, though each letter not connected to others will be a separate piece with this program. For my purposes, I had to graft them together with a small 0.1mm "thread" in the design before exporting. Make sure the thread doesn't appear above the button blank.

In modifying this, I removed the part that holds the threaded rod in place, to reduce the Z wobble induced by the threaded rods I was using.
Still using these mounts, even though I have switched to lead screws.

title: Dial Indicator Mount for Stock Rostock Max V2

description.text:
I did not like any of the dial indicator mounts I found, so I designed this one.
It will mount on the top of the hot end mount, next to the hot end, and extend down through the effector plate.
You will need an extension for the indicator. This is designed to work with 3/8" barrels on the dial indicator.

You will need 2 #6-32x2in screws to mount this to your Rostock

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%
The mount with my long travel dial indicator mounted into it. The mount from the front From the top, the dial indicator mounts back and to the left.
